resources.string: A hypothetical future popularized by Hax where everyone plays Fox frame-perfectly. Since the only thing determining the winner of a match is port priority, the Rock-Paper-Scissors metagame has evolved \"to ridiculous levels\" and has become the only remaining factor to decide the outcome of matches. The 20XX Hack Pack and 20XX Tournament Edition are also popular mods for Melee.

A technique performed by full presing the L or R button in the air. Air dodging halts momentum, gives intangibility frames to the user, and it can be angled using the control stick to give a small boost in a direction. It leaves the user in the helpless state after use.

A mechanic in Melee where if a player's combo count is greater than or equal to 5 while grounded, the player is pushed backwards by an invisible force at a rate of 0.025 meleemeters/frame. As the combo grows to 13 or more, the rate of pushback is increased to 0.070 meleemeters/frame. More info: http://bit.ly/1Zw0lvE
Similar to a pop-off, but not as significant and more subtle.
Stages that are banned from most tournaments for providing an unfair advantage for certain characters such as infinites, stalling, or lethal environments.
A grudge held against another person.

A blastzone is a boundary on a stage that a character cannot cross without getting KO'd (in most cases). Most stages contain blast zones that are far away from any sides. Can be viewed in the stages section.
An alternate name for Peach's down smash, which can deal multiple hits and a significant amount of damage if used on a player who is crouch cancelling.
A Falco combo that uses shine to Up-B at the top of the stage for an early kill.
Boost grabbing is an advanced technique in which the momentum from a character's dash attack is transferred into a dash grab, resulting in a longer-ranged dash grab. http://bit.ly/1Yoaslw

A tournament standard in which a player's matches are played between two entrants, resulting in the winner advancing to play another player the next round and the loser being eliminated from the tournament.
An improvement in a character or a certain aspect of a character, usually through an update.
A combo that involves several unorthodox moves to try to \"build\" a combo. https://clips.twitch.tv/srkevo1/FrailCoyoteMcaT
A fraud; someone who didn't meet expectaions.
When a character charges a smash attack, they turn yellow like butter. \"He put a lot of butter into that one\"
Bring Your Own Controller to tournaments. They won't supply controllers.
The box of a stage where the camera is watching. The blastzones are usually past or at this box. Can be viewed in the stages section.
Canceling an action with another action or nothing at all.

An enclosed area in a stage where characters can survive to much higher percentages than usual. These areas have an impassable platform above the area, and can contain other walls, which allows characters to tech and survive potentially fatal blows. Even without teching, characters will bounce off the ceiling, which absorbs some of the knockback, and allows the character to survive longer than usual.

Refers to WestBallz's play, who is infamous for accidentally SD'ing in the middle of a combo. This term can also mean accidentally Side-B'ing off the stage or dying in some unreasonable avoidable way. https://youtu.be/hBzLIB1iSXM
A character who has a nearly identical moveset to another with slight variation.
When a Fox or Falco throws out a Forward Smash at a seemingly random moment with or without intention, but the move hits. Named after the greatest anime of all time.
Counter is the down special move for Marth and Roy. It is used as a counterattack to deliver damage to the attacker when the user is hit.
The act of choosing a character or stage in order to have the advantage on the opponent in the next round.
A battle when teams of players share a group of stocks, Whichever team is runs out of stocks first loses. More info: www.ssbwiki.com/Crew_battle
A form of ground movement faster than walking. It is performed by tapping sideways on the control stick.
A variation of a grab that is performed by pressing the grab button while dashing.
A rule that no stage that has already been won on in a set may be picked by the winner for another game in the same set. It was named after the smasher Scamp.
A moment when 2 players hit each other at the same time and fly offstage in opposite directions, and KO at nearly the same time. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3MiydNxcUh8
A nickname for the Falcon Punch, originating from when Mango's son said the phrase while using the move on stream. http://oddshot.tv/shot/mang0-2016030804425983

string.name: didyouwalkupslowly_term_info
string.title: Did he just walk up slowly and down smash?

resources.string: A quote from Scar commentating Mango (Falcon) vs. Hax (Fox) at TBH4. Mango picked Falcon to make fun of Hax's decision to switch to Fox as he was arguably the best Falcon at the time. https://youtu.be/3NMhGCf20i0
A hitbox that is separated from a character's hurtbox, such as Marth's sword.
When someone uses a non-optimal and stylish option to deliberately make their opponent feel bad about themselves, such as spiking someone who was not going to make it back to the stage anyways.
A match where both players choose the same character. Also known as a mirror match.
A shortened version of \"Donkey Kong\", used mostly in \"Expand dong\".
When a player gets stomped (dair'd) on by Captain Falcon or Ganondorf 3 or more times in a row.
When a Falco uses his Dair to spike a character twice in a row, sometimes after a jump or walljump. http://oddshot.tv/shot/beyondthesummit-2015110913256628
The 2 vs 2 part of a tournament. Doubles requires a different strategy, namely teamwork, to defeat opponents.
Getting a premature kill off the edge using any sort of meteor smash or spike, specifically Marth's Dair or Falco's Dair
A Sheik combo that ends with an Up Smash
Quote from smasher Bizzarro Flame at Apex 2015, when asked what he thought when Ganon main Eikelmann would be going against him, Bizzarro replied \"EASY MONEY!\". https://youtu.be/97fQoffpJiM

Stands for Environmental Collision Box, and is the \"bones\" of a character model in Melee. The orientation and size changes of the ECB in certain moves allow for techniques like aerial interrupting and no-impact landing to occur.
The attempt to prevent an off-stage recovering opponent from reaching the stage, thus causing them to be KO'd.
Due to only one character being able to hold onto the ledge, you can cause your opponent to miss it when they are recovering due to you currently taking it.
When a Samus super wavedashes into a charge shot.

An alternate name for Yoshi's Story, which is often a counterpick for Falco players. Falco benefits from this stage due to its low platforms and small vertical blastzones, making it easy for Falco to get a kill from a spike.
To make a mistake or an error.

Coined by top Young Link main Axe, Young Link can take advantage of the boomerang glitch which allows him to ledge stall extremely easily. Explanation by Axe: http://oddshot.tv/shot/az-axe-201512092547403 http://oddshot.tv/shot/az-axe-2015120925418797

A frame is the primary unit of time in Melee. Every frame, the game reads controller input, performs calculations, and renders an image on the screen, one frame is 1/60th of a second, meaning the game runs at 60 fps (frames per second).

The frames during which a character will freeze for a period of time after connecting with an attack. If an attack hits successfully, both the attacker and target are frozen in time for a number of frames. Also known as hitlag.
An match played with a competitive ruleset but is used for practice or just for fun in general.
Similar to wavecheating, this is a comical term used to make fun of L-canceling.
The action of KOing a recovering opponent by interrupting their recovery

A comical phrase meant to refer to Mew2King's lack of medical support in response to his hand injuries. Mew2King had been playing Melee competitively for several years without proper stretching or treatment, causing hand and finger pains. Make sure you stretch with the information provided in this app before, during, and after playing. https://youtu.be/9JTqydWaioc
One of the Top 5 players in Melee, called Gods as they are all-powerful and rule the tournaments. The players are Mango, Mew2King, PPMD, Hungrybox and Armada.
To go completely crazy on someone, performing the best you possibly can against them.

The action of grabbing and holding an opponent. Regular grabs are performed by pressing either the shield and A buttons simultaneously, or by pressing Z. Once grabbed, a character can be thrown by tilting the control stick in any of the four standard directions, or pummeled with the A or Z button.
A comical name for when a Donkey Kong combos a Down-air into a charged Up-smash. https://www.gfycat.com/PertinentThatAffenpinscher
A more formal name for Randall the Cloud. https://clips.twitch.tv/beyondthesummit/LivelyMonkeyKreygasm
When a Fox or Falco SD's by falling off the stage and using their fair. The term's name is due to the move looking like a helicopter.
A state in which characters are unable to take any action, with the exception of grabbing a ledge, maneuvering left/right, fastfalling, or climbing a ladder, until they land on the ground.

The main structure for how attacks are executed in most fighting games. Attacks have one or more hitboxes associated with them, and when these hitboxes overlap with a target's hurtbox, the attack is considered a hit. Hitboxes are invisible spheres and usually have the same shape as the attack's animation.

The frames during which a character will freeze for a period of time after connecting with an attack. If an attack hits successfully, both the attacker and target are frozen in time for a number of frames. Also known as freeze frames.
A period of time after being hit by an attack that a character is unable to perform any actions other than DI or teching.
The damageable area of a target. When the hitboxes of an attack collide with a target's hurtbox, an attack is considered a hit.
Interruptible As Soon As. The earliest point at when you can act during or after an attack.
Any move or technique which can be maintained indefinitely, either through skill or a glitch, while preventing an opponent's escape.
Input lag is either the delay between the television or monitor receiving a signal and it being displayed on the screen or the delay between pressing a button and seeing the game react.

A glitch in Melee that resets the victim's vertical velocity to zero upon activation. Most commonly, this makes a character knocked upward appear to get hit by an invisible ceiling, seemingly being stage spiked downward. This glitch infamously resulted in S2J losing a set to Abate at The Big House 5. http://oddshot.tv/shot/vgbootcamp-2015100417555965 http://www.gfycat.com/GregariousHauntingDrafthorse

An ironman is a special type of match where 2 players select 5 different characters, and match their opponent with 3 stocks per character. Whichever player runs out of stocks first loses. http://smashboards.com/threads/the-ironman-match.110560/

A phrase commentators use to say that a certain action isn't safe to perform, most often spoken in response to a Falco LHDL'ing and getting punished. http://oddshot.tv/shot/beyondthesummit-2015110625841140
Something that happens that is just weird, buggy, or not working as you would expect it to. https://youtu.be/iF9_EpCGfSs
When a player gets a 0-death with just one combo. The term is named after Johnny Kim, aka S2J.
A john is an excuse. Remember people, if you lose you lose. No johns. http://poyoarya.github.io/john.html
Repeatedly hitting your opponent above you to prevent them from landing.
Canceling an action with a jump, most notable example are the shines of Falco and Fox.
Link Down throw to Up-B, done several times by my friend Junco.
A JV3 stock is when you win with 2 stocks and 0% damage, same for JV4 but with 3 stocks instead. Basically a 4 stock but you died from the last hit you took. Popularized by smasher JV3x3.
An emoticon on Twitch.tv used to convey sarcasm. "If you main Fox you'll lose your hands, Kappa."

The Ken combo refers to a spike setup with Marth discovered and popularized by professional Marth player, Ken. It consists of a single jump, forward aerial; midair jump, down aerial. https://youtu.be/OR1pNBmT7NM
A waveshine followed by a instant shine offstage. https://youtu.be/yJmx3v27olQ?t=3m4s
An emoticon on Twitch.tv used to convey an intense feeling of elation or pleasure. One commonly used phrase is "PPMD Kreygasm".
The downtime period the occurs before or after performing certain attacks or actions.
The time where an attack is interrupted by landing and the character is unable to act, can usually be shortened with L-canceling.
When a player runs to the ledge and turns around (using the ledge to cancel their turn around animation) and then wavedashes to ledge.
People joking about what stages should be legal, saying the once legal stage "PokeFloats" should be legal. It was considered not legal due to the lack of ledges characters can grab onto.
A twitch meme, now expanded to all of the smash community. Origin: http://pastebin.com/YZj6B2Wt
When a Captain Falcon hits an opponent with the later weak hitbox of his FAir (Knee).
When a player unplugs something, named after MacD after being accused of sabotaging MVG Sandstorm (A tournament) http://oddshot.tv/shot/armadaugs-201603231601580
A mangle is when a player (usually a Fox or Falco) gets back onto the stage using their Up-B in an odd or unexpected angle, somehow avoiding an attack from the person guarding the edge.
A meme in the Smash Bros. community where if a player isn't playing in a tournament it means he's in prison. https://clips.twitch.tv/beyondthesummit/ExcitedWolfOSsloth
A comical misspelling of Masahiro Sakurai, the director of all Smash Bros. games. Other misspellings are MassiveHero SoccerGuy, and Mashed potato Sack of Rye

An approximation of difficulty of all possible matches for any given character against any other character based on two players of equal skill. Also used to talk about matches between characters or players.
Metagame is a broad term usually used to define any strategy, action or method used in a game which transcends a prescribed ruleset.
A move that sends someone downward, and is designated by the game as a special. Weaker than a spike and can be canceled. https://gfycat.com/AllSpiritedGangesdolphin (Falco Side-B is a meteor)

Jumping or Up-Bing any time after 8 frames after you are hit by a meteor smash. Causes a little sound effect and flashy graphic. https://gfycat.com/AllSpiritedGangesdolphin (First Up-B is a meteor cancel)
To have your smash career ended by a Falcon Punch. Popularized after smasher Mike Haze's destruction by Falcon Punches. https://youtu.be/XSgklDhaZR0
A series of deliberate actions or responses planned for psychological effect on another, typically for amusement or competitive advantage. Messing with your opponent.
There is a 12.5% chance where Luigi's Green Missile (Side-B) can misfire, causing his speed and horizontal distance covered to increase dramatically.

The act of getting recognition in Smash, purposely losing to a selected opponent that is formidable in a less important tournament and then waiting for their match analysis of them defeating you because they felt good, followed by you studying that match analysis in order to destroy them in a more major tournament. Discovered by HugS https://youtu.be/qCKaD7i-zNk
A shortened version of "My bad". Used by Chillindude. https://youtu.be/1TO7MdV5qZo
A term used to describe a decline in a character or a certain aspect of a character, usually through an update.
When neither players have a positional advantage.
A diss track from Chillindude towards HugS, just being a friendly banter. https://youtu.be/DKH3iHIj0Qc
Stands for Out Of Shield. Meaning to perform an action out of a shield, such as grab or Up-B.
When an aspect of a character is believed to be too powerful, sometimes shorted to OP and usually followed by a "pls nerf sakurai".
Also called ledge turn around grab, done by walking to the ledge and doing a slow turn around, followed by fast fall. Used to quickly edge hog. https://youtu.be/yw9pfO9UORU
A nickname for Captain Falcon's side smash. Named after MIOM Co-Founder of MIOM Scar, who is nicknamed "The People's Champ".
If you barely hit your opponent, you'll do half damage and deal no knockback. All that is visible is the percent change and the visual hit effect. https://youtu.be/iAHw6z0j074
When your moonwalk is so smooth it's like you just cleaned the floor, coined by my boy Juan (CREED_).
When you try to recover below Dreamland but get stuck, similar to what happens when you recover towards the bottom of Battlefield.
When you quickly turn around to perform an action, can be done with any move.
When a Sheik unloads a full set of needles onto a Jigglypuff.
When a smasher shows emotion after an action is performed, usually "popping" off their chair. Can be a positive or negative reaction. http://gfycat.com/FatWhoppingDikdik

The gameplay mechanic that uses the ports to determine the outcome of certain situations between characters, during matches. Lower the port number, higher the priority. Usually simultaneous actions (such as grabbing) are determined by port priority.

The range of an attack. For example, Marth's Forward Smash has much greater Priority than that of Pichu. Moves with greater priority can override those with less. Due to the fact they reach the hurtbox before the opponents move does.
Tapping A during a grab to deal small damage to your opponent.
When a player exploits a mistake of their opponent, such as a missed tech, improper input or bad judgement.
When a player steals the ledge from another player almost instantly, as if the player stealing the ledge got to it a frame before the other.
The cloud that flies around the stage in Yoshis Story. Timing for Randall explained: http://oddshot.tv/shot/bleagel0-2015122203619419
The Up-B attack is usually referred to as the recovery since it is how most characters recover their position on top of the stage.
A diss track from Chillindude towards Leffen, in hype for Apex 2015. Leffen then 5-0's Chillin. https://youtu.be/KhsOW-_TwfU
Random chance. Usually associated with Peach's Down-B or Game & Watch's Side-B. People jokingly say to pray to "RNGsus" in order for a player's RNG chances to be in their favor.
Hitting left or right on the control or c stick while shielding. Not used very often in Melee.
Falcon knee (fair) to Falcon Punch (Neutral-B) https://youtu.be/MlGM0BFv3JU
The opposite of the sacred combo, a Falcon Punch to knee (fair). https://youtu.be/GOevcqeb6w4
A combo that involves the Up-B of Fox or Falco. https://youtu.be/XLuYNzCnhWI
A word used to describe someone who is upset. (mainly because of their loss to someone) https://youtu.be/zTVOjo05_E0
The act of losing a match and angrily (or jokingly) demanding a rematch from your opponent in the same stage, with the same characters.
Like a clone, but has enough variation to separate it distinctly from who it's based on.

Tapping the c-stick back lightly on a ledge grab so you can fall while keeping your second jump and be close enough to do some wall jump stalling edgeguards. Captain Falcon and Young link get the most out of this. Used and popularized by Scar. https://youtu.be/feXYCJKct0s
A KO when an opponent goes past the top blast zone and ends up hitting the screen.
Often abbreviated as SD, means when someone kills themselves, whether on purpose or accident.
Usually in best of three (Bo3) or best of five matches (Bo5), singles or doubles, which ever player or team wins 2 for Bo3, or 3 for Bo5, wins the set.

Refers to any neutral air kick attack that does damage after the kick. The attack gets weaker the longer it is out, with the exception of Dr. Mario. Bair on Fox and Falco constitute as Sex Kicks as well.
When you make plays (moments where you make good decisions in your play). Coined by Prince Abu.
When an opponent breaks your shield and you input jab on their controller, so they don't have a chance to punish the shield break.
Pressing A or Z while in shield will have your character grab, can be used to punish attacks.

With each hit inflicted within a period of time, the shield will become smaller until it is broken. This results in the character being thrown up, and being stunned for a few moments after landing. Characters with more damage will be stunned for less time.
The frames during which you can't do anything after hitting a shield.

Pressing and holding R or L when on the ground will have a circle which blocks attacks come up. The size, strength, and deterioration of a shield is dependent upon your character and how far you hold down L or R.
An effect similar to hitstun, but when a character is in shield and the opponent hits the shield.
Fox and Falco's Down Special (Down-B). While Falco's sends the opponent upwards, Fox's spikes at a set knockback and diagonally downward angle.
A technique with Fox and Falco, lets the player drop through a platform with a shine. Done in a similar action to shield dropping. Used to trigger shine mines.
To dodge and stay in place, also called spot dodge. Done by shielding downward on the ground.
When a player fixes the cable of their controller after losing a stock, it's a john saying the cable is messing them up, but they fix it silently.
One on one smashing, has its own bracket at tourneys.
Attacks done by inputting a direction with the c-stick or the control stick and A at the same time. Deals more knockback and more damage than a tilt, but has more start up and end lag.

HugS's theory of Smash Inflation is that, because there are so few female smashers, and they are surrounded by so many male smashers, female smashers automatically gain about 2 points on a hotness scale. So a normal girl could be a 4, but be a 6 at a smash tourney. Additionally, just being related to a smasher increases hotness, which is why Mike Haze's mom is so hot.
Parties or events aimed at playing smash with several others.
A hitbox that is usually weaker and deals less knockback than its stronger counterpart, the sweetspot hitbox. One example is the sourspot Zelda's F-air and B-air.

A comical nickname meant to refer to the Star Fox crew members, Fox and Falco, as they are quite literally space animals. And are characters that space themselves from the opponent. Sometimes referred to as spacie animals or spacies.
A type of attack that sends an opponent downward until hitstun ends. https://gfycat.com/AllSpiritedGangesdolphin (Falco dair spikes)
Not only the fastest way to crouch, it's also the slowest way of moving your character forward. Instead of crouching downward rapidly, you aim more of a diagonal down. https://youtu.be/-9bpqdRZl58
When a character is hit towards the stage when under, and the missed tech causes the player to bounce downward, essentially spiking the player. Usually followed by a "We tech those".
When a Fox up-airs a lightweight character to the ceiling of the map to KO. https://clips.twitch.tv/srkevo1/PlainLarkVaultBoy
The term used to reference a mechanic in Smash how moves cause less damage and knockback as they are used multiple times in a row.
When you KO an opponent towards to top killbox and the blast off away in the background.

Peach's Down-B has several different variations, many being stronger than the normal one. One of the more notable being the "stitch face", which can deal 33-41% when thrown. https://youtu.be/8Nnr3L0DBeQ
A comical term meant to refer to SD'ing or when a player's mistake or mindlessness results in them losing a stock.
Like wave dashing but downwards.
To play for looks, usually spoken as "Style out". Meaning to perform in a way that is just visually satisfying. https://youtu.be/N7u46_7AvJA
An offstage falling U-Air by Fox. http://gfycat.com/VibrantClutteredInchworm

A hitbox that is usually much stronger and deals more knockback than its weaker counterpart, the sourspot hitbox. Once this hitbox appears in a move and is out for a short time, it is replaced by the sourspot for the remainder of the move. One example is Captain Falcon's fair.

When a character uses a special attack (usually Up-B) to target a ledge and they end up grabbing the ledge right out of the special attack, usually done to get invincibility (from ledge grabbing) and avoid an opponent guarding the lege from them.
Tool Assisted Speedrun is a presentation produced by using features such as slow motion or frame-by-frame advance of the gameplay in order to play it (frame) perfectly. https://youtu.be/l1PYPAYWTII
A technique done for mindgames or humorous purpose where the player cancels their taunt animation with a ledge. Can be done with Young Link and Dr. Mario.

When a player combos on their opponent in a way that a missed tech leads to another opportunity to tech, but due to the 40 frame lockout for techs, the player being hit is forced to miss the tech, and then is punished.
A phrasing stating the Super Smash Bros. Melee God Mew2King is back, meaning he is placing well in tournaments.
Captain Falcon's Fair. Renown for its usability and power.
When a player performs the slow jump get up at a ledge, which is easily punishable, hence leading to the player winning the tournament.
When a Falco wavedashes off of a platform, and double jumps into bair to edge guard. Named after Zhu.
A kill performed with the top hitbox of Marth's Up Smash. Name is given from the pose used in the animated TV show, Thundercats. https://youtu.be/EdhE0IdiUII

A extremely impressive combo for Fox. Short hop-> Down Air(L-cancelled)-> Waveshine -> Jab Reset-> Short hop towards opponent-> Falling Up Air(L-cancelled)-> Charged Up Smash http://i.imgur.com/fl9Uov4.gifv
In gaming, a tier list is a list that ranks all characters based on metagame, effectiveness of strategies, moveset, statistics, matchups, and tournament results.
A quick, weak attack done by tilting the stick in any direction and pressing A while on the ground.
A deliberate misspelling of "Tiers don't exist", it is an inside joke among the Smash community.

A mind-game technique that involves jumping or short hopping and then landing without doing anything. Tricks your opponent to think an aerial is about to be performed, causing them to pull out their shield, so you can punish with a grab.
A different way of saying tournament.

Traction is a measure of how long it takes for a character to stop moving from a sideways force when grounded. Characters with low traction slide farther than others after walking, dashing, wavedashing, being hit by an attack while grounded, and so on.
When two players hit each other and get hit by their opponent's attacks at the same time. Usually results in both players flying apart.

A comical term meant to refer to Smash 4, the 4th iteration of Super Smash Bros. which is on the Wii U and 3DS. People also use Connect 4, Snore 4 and TR4SH. Please be respectful to all players of the Smash community.
Similar to wave dashing but after the jump has initially performed, usually done to space oneself from the opponent, such as a Marth triangle jumping back to properly sweet spot the sword.
Quickly sticking the control stick the opposite direction you're facing before performing your neutral B will make you turn around and then perform the special.
The opposite of a sex kick. The longer it stays out the stronger it gets.
Moving by slowly pressing the control stick left or right, tilts can be done from this and it is slower than dashing.
A stage where you can walk all the way through the sides, reaching the blast zone. Walk-off edge stages are illegal because players can abuse them for early KOs.

A technique with Jigglypuff taking advantage of her multiple jumps to barrage or gimp players. Some times done to knock the player out of the side camera box using Jigg's bair or nair. https://youtu.be/ZknGCSjgDMY
A comical term used referring to wavedashing when it is thought to be OP by players. Usually spoken as "Stahp wavecheating guise".
Like dash-dancing, but with wavedashes.

The most recognizable Smash video, referring to a California Tournament match with an impromptu combo by SilentSpectre and Tang against Zhu with commentary by HomeMadeWaffles, Phil, and MaNgo. Sometimes used to refer to a team combo that uses different moves. The origin of "DAT AINT FALCO". https://youtu.be/pD_imYhNoQ4
A nickname for Mewtwo's Up-B, in which he teleports with a "woop" sound being played when he vanishes and reappears.
Controlling a specific area of a stage in order to have the most advantageous position.
